Santa F.. N.M. 
March 28th, 1889
Commission Indian Affairs
Washington
Yous 22nd recieved. I shall move the indians.

good service in preventing illegal squatters from cutting hay on, or removing it from the reservation.  In fact cheerfully furnishing all detail for the services required judging from your letter of the 6th and one of the 8th inst. just received from the Surveyor (here with enclosed) for I think a still further delay probable during which I propose to continue and complete my personal examination and apprisement of all improvement known to be on the reservation.  I have been thus engaged for the past four weeks (driving from 25 to 40 miles daily) and am now having a pack train with [strike] and military escort with company outfit &c, and will leave here on the 13th hoping to make the entire round by the 20, when I shall complete my report as directed by your letter of -- no -- when I will be ready for other duty unless the out boundry survey shall be completed.

    Mr. Stallstiners (the local agent here) informs me that he finds a post (burnt off) lying on the ground at a point where the D & RG R R crosses the Colorado State line in Sec 11 T 32 N Range 3 West said post being marked SECSUR which he construes to be the South East Corner of Southern Ute Reservation and hence claims that to be the 107 degree of West longitude thus trhowing out (for the use of settlers) some seven miles of the east end of the Southern Ute Reserve

and says he shall refuse to erect any building upon the Agency site selected by me (under authority by latter dated Washington Mch 22- 1887).  In Sec 12 (T) 31 N. R. 2 W. he believing this take seven miles off the reservation, for the above reasons I think it essential that the entire out boundary should be speedily and officially surveyed, also the eastern boundary of the Ute reservation be officially determined and clearly marked.  If but a part of this work can be done, then the east line of T 32 and and N half of T 31 N in R 2 W is the most essential and next is the entire West line of the reservation

                                                Your obd Servt
                                                        H. S. Welton
                                                                Special Agent

To Hon
J. D. C. Askin
Commr
Washington

n.d.
On the bluff of the little Big-orn
At the close of a woful day
Custer and his three hundred
In deth and silence lay
Three hundred to three thousand
They had bravely fought an bled
For such is the will of Congress
When the White man meets the red
The White men are ten millions
The thriftiest under the sun
The reds are fifty thousand
And warriors every one
So Custer and all his fighting
Lay under the evening skies
Staring up at the tranquil heaven
With wide accusing eyes

{with map 2}
Little River, C. H. 20 Feby 1869
Genl Grierson
Fort Gibson

         About five miles this side (west) of where I met you is a creek known as the twenty five mile creek, and about a quarter of a mile this side (west) of the creek, the road forks.   The right hand, (the one you went) is known as the "old shop road" and has not been used for fifteen years.  The left hand, is the traveled road, and about eight or ten miles from the first fork, as above, it forks again.  Either fork goes

to Little River, although the right hand is said [underlined word] to be the shortest and best.   

       I have never traveled the right hand, as I always go to the left [underlined word] and it is an excellent road, but needs a little, (very little however) work to make it first class.  There are two hills upon it, but not bad ones, and can be made good with but little work.
       I enclose you a rough map (my first attempt).  It is of course not well proportioned as to distance &c, but it will, I hope

serve to give you an idea of the road from here to North Fork Town.

    You took the wrong road at Lasleu AAdaines I suppose, which is on Grave creek about 9 miles from here.  I am told that the right hand I spoke of not having ever traveled, comes in there, but am inclined to think it must be further east, (at the next creek likely). Somewhere along there, you took the left [underlined word], when you should have taken the right [word underlined].
       When I got to the fork of

the road, about five miles from where I met you, I saw that you had come down the old road, and was not surprised at your thinking it rough.  The road as travelled now a days, is a very good road, and can be made first class with but little work, and being of a very sandy nature, can b e traveled when no other road can.

       Another advantage is that there are no large streams, and travelers are scarcely ever delayed beyond a few hours by high water.
       Hoping that this may remove any unfavorable impression you may have received as to the road here to North Fork Town, I have the honor to be Genl
                                                    Yours Respectfully
                                                                  Wm Hird

[1886]
Description of Fort Selden NM
Established May 8th 1865 occupied
June 1865, Reservation declared bu the
President Nov.28.1871 and announced
in G.O. No.1 [?] Dept of MO Jan 9 1871
Reservation contains 15 sq miles and 9615 73/100
acres.  The Fort was abandoned August 8th 1878 and re-occupied December 25, 1880
Elevation above sea level 3953 feet
[?] temperature in Summer @ 7am 73 degrees
[?] temperature in Summer @ 2pm 93 degrees
[?] temperature in Winter @ 7am 35 degrees
[?] temperature in Winter @ 2pm 55 degrees
The Post is situated in a sandy, crescent shaped
basin about 1/2 mile from the Rio Grand and 
about 4 miles from the Southern Extremity
of the Jornado del Mudo.  The soil is sandy
and alkaline and is not adapted to agriculture.
All that part of the [?] lying
between the Rail Road and the river as
shown on the map is arable but has
not been cleared to any extent and coals
only be cultivated and irrigation.  The only
lumber in the immediate vicinity is on the 
bottom land above [?] and consists
almost entirely of cotton wood
Gramma grass is found on the Jornado and
was formerly depended upon for the

hay supply of the Post.  The Rio Grande
is subject to overflows.  In 1884 the
flood destroyed the railroad and 
prevented the passage of trains for 71 days,
again this season. [1886] the river has 
been very high causing [?] 
embarrassment to the railroad on account 
of [?].  It is fordable during low
water and at various places int he vicinity
but it is more or less dangerous on account
of quick sands.  There is not ferry attached
to the port and none in the vicinity
the only ferry on the river now known
being at old Fort McRae about sixty
miles north.  The seasons are dry.  the 
climate mild, and generally speaking the
port is healthy.  The R.T. station is about
200 yards from the port.  Good roads
to forts.  Bliss and Slanton the Mercaleo Indian
Agency at Fort Bayard, by the way
of old Fort Cumming's [?] all 
the year round.  Excepting to Cummings and
Bayard when impeded by high water in the 
Rio Grande.
